Two title naming issues relative to standard Spain Spanish legal terminology: (1) "Derecho Penal Procesal" is typically "Derecho Procesal Penal"; (2) "Derecho Penal Internacional" is more commonly "Derecho Internacional Penal". Everything else follows Title Case, avoids levels/joiners, and descriptions are in Spanish and one sentence.

Rename to the standard forms noted above; consider adding closely related single-topic courses to broaden coverage (e.g., "Derecho Penitenciario", "Política Criminal", "Victimología"); optionally replace "Derecho Penal Sustantivo" with Spain-typical formulations like "Parte General del Derecho Penal" or "Parte Especial del Derecho Penal" if targeting Spain usage.

steps.conclusion: Two title typos: 1) "Téléométrie et Analyse des Performances en Formule 1" should be "Télémétrie..." (accent error); 2) "Règlementation et Sécurité en Formule 1" should be "Réglementation..." (incorrect accent). These are significant because titles must look like real courses and spelling mistakes reduce credibility.

Some titles are stylistically awkward in French: "Formule 1 Technologie et Ingénierie" lacks a preposition; more natural would be "Technologie et ingénierie de la Formule 1"; "Physique et Dynamique des Châssis en Formule 1" could read more naturally as "Dynamique du châssis en Formule 1"; "F1" as a standalone title may be a bit too terse for a course title though acceptable per brief.

Correct the two spelling errors in titles; rephrase "Formule 1 Technologie et Ingénierie" to "Technologie et ingénierie de la Formule 1"; optionally rephrase "Physique et Dynamique des Châssis en Formule 1" for naturalness; consider adding a broader alternative like "Sport Automobile" and targeted topics such as "Aérodynamique de la Formule 1" or "Gestion des Pneus en Formule 1"; optionally include a canonical "Formule 1" title alongside "F1".
